SEARCH
Package io.github.istarwyh.junit5.provider

Class JsonFileArgumentsProvider

java.lang.Object
io.github.istarwyh.junit5.provider.JsonFileArgumentsProvider
All Implemented Interfaces:
Consumer<JsonFileSource>, org.junit.jupiter.params.provider.ArgumentsProvider, org.junit.jupiter.params.support.AnnotationConsumer<JsonFileSource>
public class JsonFileArgumentsProvider extends Object implements org.junit.jupiter.params.support.AnnotationConsumer<JsonFileSource>, org.junit.jupiter.params.provider.ArgumentsProvider
Provides a way to supply arguments to parameterized tests in JUnit 5 by reading JSON files specified by the JsonFileSource annotation. This class implements the ArgumentsProvider interface, which is part of the JUnit Jupiter Params API, and the AnnotationConsumer interface to consume the JsonFileSource annotations.

The JsonFileArgumentsProvider is responsible for locating the JSON files specified in the annotation, reading their contents, and converting them into objects of the type expected by the test method parameters. It supports both simple and generic types, including handling of recursive type references by setting them to null to prevent infinite loops during JSON parsing.

Usage of this class requires the @JsonFileSource annotation to be present on the test method with one or more JSON file resources specified. The class will then read each file, deserialize the JSON content into the required parameter type, and provide it as arguments to the parameterized test.

Example usage: 


 @ParameterizedTest
 @JsonFileSource(resources = "yourTestData.json")
 void testWithJsonFileSource(YourCustomType customArgument) {
     assertNotNull(customArgument);
     // Perform tests with the deserialized customArgument object
 }
Detailed example usage can be seen in the JsonFileArgumentsProviderTest.

Note that this class relies on the JSON library for JSON processing and uses the EasyRandom library for generating random values for object instantiation when needed. It also makes use of SneakyThrows to bypass checked exceptions, which should be used cautiously as it may hide potentially recoverable errors.

This class is part of a suite of extensions that enhance JUnit 5's parameterized testing capabilities, allowing for more flexible and data-driven test cases.

Author:
xiaohui
